Data model CDSL –
Documentation
CCeH (MG/FM)
2015

1. The TEI CSL project

The TEI Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon (TEI CSL) project is the continuation of the Cologne Digital Sanskrit Lexicon (CDSL) project. The CDSL started in the mid 90s and has by now digitised 34 Sanskrit dictionaries and made them available online. These 34 dictionaries are all accessible via individual web applications. The dictionaries are internally stored as XML-files using different kinds of xml-specifications, displaying considerable differences in mark-up, data structures, and internal complexity. The goal of the TEI CSL is to represent all 34 dictionaries in unified TEI-conformant mark-up and make them accessible through a single web application, which displays entries from the different dictionaries consistently and allows simultaneous queries in multiple dictionaries.

In a first phase, we have transformed the following three dictionaries into the TEI format:

  • monier: Monier Williams Sanskrit-English Dictionary (second edition, 1899), [the old place]
  • pwg: Boehtlingk & Roth Sanskrit-German Dictionary, [the old place]
  • aptestud: Apte English Sanskrit Dictionary, [the old place]

2. TEI data model - customization done for the Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon

The mark-up specifications used in the TEI CSL are a restricted subset of the standard TEI model and we tried to find solutions within the standard TEI model whenever possible.

Customizations done:
  • we included only the modules we needed and excluded the elements we are not making use of (work in progress).
  • we used the attribute ana in various elements as a container for the elementnames of our source files.

3. Conversion of the files: from source XML to TEI

The conversion of the different original versions of the CDSL XML was defined by a set of XSL Transformations for each dictionary. The main objective of the transformations was to preserve all information contained in the original files, while tranferring the content into a standardized and well-documented format. Thomas Malten and the editors working on the original xml file encoded a lot of linguistic and grammatical information in the specific names of the elements. We tried to transfer these elements into functionally and semantically corresponding TEI elements: However, we decided to document the original element by preserving the element name as a value of ana (in some cases in addition value).

In case of monier we could make use of an existing markup documentation to understand the specifically coded information and transfer it to the TEI standard using XSLT.

Because there is was no such documentation for the other two dictionaries, we simply searched for similar patterns and consulted the printed book to understand what had been encoded.

3.1. The structure of the dictionaries

Although the represented lexicographic data is highly structured and the hierarchical structure is indicated by typographic means in the original printed editions, all of the three source xml files showed mostly flat structures: This meant that nesting had to be build up during the transformation of the original flat XML into TEI. By building a structural hierarchy for all three dictionaries, we were able to conform to the structure of TEI and the logic of the TEI dictionaries module especially.

3.1.1. Monier

The source xml file of the Monier Williams dictionary uses H1 to mark entries for top-level lemma. Subordinate entries (like H2, H3, H4 and variants marked by a A,B,C like H1A, H1B) are not nested but simply follow the <H1> they belong to. The next <H1> opens a new top level keyword.

The markup documentation for the source xml says: "There are four basic H elements, named H1,H2,H3,H4; these are intended to correspond to the 'four mutually correlated lines of Sanskrit words' described at Page xiv: Section II of the dictionary preface" (See the facsimile for further information).

Example from our monier source file:
<H1>  <h>   <hc3>000</hc3>   <key1>a</key1>   <hc1>1</hc1>   <key2>a</key2>   <hom>1</hom>  </h>  <body>   <c>the_first_letter_of_the_alphabet</c>  </body>  <tail>   <pc>Page1,1</pc>   <L>1</L>  </tail> </H1> <H1A>  <h>   <hc3>000</hc3>   <key1>a</key1>   <hc1>1</hc1>   <key2>a</key2>   <hom>1</hom>  </h>  <body>   <c>the_first_short_vowel_inherent_in_consonants.</c>  </body>  <tail>   <pc>Page1,1</pc>   <MW>000001</MW>   <L>1.1</L>  </tail> </H1A> <H3>  <h>   <hc3>110</hc3>   <key1>akAra</key1>   <hc1>3</hc1>   <key2>a--kAra</key2>  </h>  <body>   <lex>m.</lex>   <c>the_letter_or_sound</c>   <s>a</s>. </body>  <tail>   <MW>000002</MW>   <pc>1,1</pc>   <L>2</L>  </tail> </H3>
This structure was transformed into the following nested structure:
<entry ana="H1" n="1" xml:id="lemma-a-1">  <form>   <idno ana="hc3">000</idno>   <orth ana="key1"    xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a</orth>   <idno ana="hc1">1</idno>   <hyph ana="key2"    xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1-headword2">a</hyph>   <milestone n="1" unit="hom"/>  </form>  <sense>the first letter of the alphabet<note>    <ref target="#page-0001" type="facs">Page1,1</ref>    <idno ana="L" xml:id="monier_1">1</idno>   </note>  </sense>  <sense ana="H1A">the first short vowel inherent in    consonants.<note>    <ref target="#page-0001" type="facs">Page1,1</ref>    <idno type="MW">000001</idno>    <idno ana="L" xml:id="monier_1.1">1.1</idno>   </note>  </sense>  <re ana="H3" xml:id="lemma-akAra">   <form>    <idno ana="hc3">110</idno>    <orth ana="key1"     xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">akAra</orth>    <idno ana="hc1">3</idno>    <hyph ana="key2"     xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1-headword2">a--kAra</hyph>   </form>   <sense>    <gramGrp>     <gram ana="lex">m.</gram>    </gramGrp>      the letter or sound <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a</w>.   <note>     <idno type="MW">000002</idno>     <ref target="#page-0001" type="facs">1,1</ref>     <idno ana="L" xml:id="monier_2">2</idno>    </note>   </sense>  </re> </entry>
The original names of the elements were adopted as values of ana.

3.1.2. pwg

The source xml showed the following flat structure, with tags like <div type="e"> used to simply encode the marker a) for the following subordinate information:
<H1>  <h>   <key1>a</key1>   <key2>a</key2>   <hom>2</hom>  </h>  <body>Pronominalstamm:  <divm n="a" type="e">a)</divm> der 1sten Person,    enthalten in <s>aha/m, AvA/m, AvA/ByAm, Ava/yos, asmA/n,      asmA/Bis, asma/Byam, asma/t, asmA/kam, asmA/su</s> und    im ved. <s>asme/</s>. -- <divm n="b" type="e">b)</divm> der    3ten Person; <gram n="f">f.</gram>   <s>A</s>. Davon folgende Casusformen: <s>aya/m</s> (<s>a</s>    wird nach <s>e</s> und <s>o</s> im <ls>R2V.</ls> nicht    elidirt, <ls>P. 6, 1, 116.</ls> zwei Ausnahmen findet man    schon <ls>R2V. PRA10TIC2. 2, 19. 21:</ls>   <s>agne 'yam</s> und <s>vahate 'yam</s>), <s>asmE/, asyE/,      asmA/t, asyA/s, asya/, asmi/n, asyA/m, AByA/m, eBi/s,      ABi/s, eBya/s, ABya/s, ezA/m, AsA/m, ezu/, Asu/</s>. In    den Veden allein erscheinen überdies: Instr.Sg.m.n.  <s>enA/</s>, <gram n="f">f.</gram>   <s>ayA/</s> (beide Formen auch als Adverbia im Gebrauch);    der zu einem Adverb erstarrte Ablativ <s>A/t</s> und der    Gen. Du. <s>ayo/s</s>. Ueber die Bedeutung und die Betonung    dieser Formen s. u. <s>idam</s>. Demselben Stamme begegnen    wir ferner in <s>atas, atra, aTa, adya, aDa, anA,      aha</s>.</body>  <tail>   <L>2</L>   <pc>1-0001</pc>  </tail> </H1>
This structure was transformed into a nested structure, using <sense ana="e" n="a)"> to encode the whole section of subordinate information:
<entry ana="H1" n="2" xml:id="lemma-a-2">  <form>   <orth ana="key1"    xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a</orth>   <hyph ana="key2"    xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a</hyph>   <milestone n="2" unit="hom"/>  </form>  <sense>Pronominalstamm: <sense ana="e" n="a)">a) der 1sten      Person, enthalten in <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aha/m</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">AvA/m</w>,   <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">AvA/ByAm</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">Ava/yos</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asmA/n</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asmA/Bis</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asma/Byam</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asma/t</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asmA/kam</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asmA/su</w> und im ved.   <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asme/</w>. --   </sense>   <sense ana="e" n="b)">b) der 3ten Person;   <gramGrp>     <gram value="f">f.</gram>    </gramGrp>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">A</w>. Davon folgende      Casusformen: <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aya/m</w> (<w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a</w> wird nach <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">e</w> und <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">o</w> im <cit type="literary_source">     <bibl xml:lang="san-Latn-x-CSDL">R2V.</bibl>    </cit> nicht elidirt, <cit type="literary_source">     <bibl xml:lang="san-Latn-x-CSDL">P. 6, 1,          116.</bibl>    </cit> zwei Ausnahmen findet man schon <cit type="literary_source">     <bibl xml:lang="san-Latn-x-CSDL">R2V. PRA10TIC2. 2,          19. 21:</bibl>    </cit>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">agne</w>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">'yam</w> und <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">vahate</w>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">'yam</w>), <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asmE/</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asyE/</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asmA/t</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asyA/s</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asya/</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asmi/n</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">asyA/m</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">AByA/m</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">eBi/s</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">ABi/s</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">eBya/s</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">ABya/s</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">ezA/m</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">AsA/m</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">ezu/</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">Asu/</w>. In den Veden      allein erscheinen überdies: Instr.Sg.m.n. <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">enA/</w>, <gramGrp>     <gram value="f">f.</gram>    </gramGrp>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">ayA/</w> (beide Formen      auch als Adverbia im Gebrauch); der zu einem Adverb      erstarrte Ablativ <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">A/t</w>      und der Gen. Du. <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">ayo/s</w>. Ueber die Bedeutung und die Betonung dieser      Formen s. u. <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">idam</w>.      Demselben Stamme begegnen wir ferner in <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">atas</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">atra</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aTa</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">adya</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aDa</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">anA</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aha</w>.</sense>   <note ana="tail">    <idno ana="L" xml:id="pgw_2">2</idno>    <ref target="#page-1-0001" type="facs">1-0001</ref>   </note>  </sense> </entry>

3.1.3. aptestud

The source xml showed the following flat structure, without an explicit marking of any subordinate keywords:
<H1>  <h>   <key1>abandon</key1>   <key2>Abandon,</key2>  </h>  <body>   <b>Abandon,</b>   <i>v.      t.</i>   <s>tyaj</s> 1 P, <s>hA</s> 3 P, <s>vi-ut-   <lb/>-sfj</s> 6 P, <s>ujJ</s> 6 P, <s>apAs</s> 4 P,  <s>Ri</s> 1 P, <lb/>10, <s>muc</s> 6 P. <b>-ed.</b>   <i>a.</i>   <s>tyakta, hIna, mukta</s>   <lb/>&amp;c. <b>2</b>   <s>pApAtman, Brazwacarita;</s> ‘he was a. <lb/>to his    fate’ <s>dEvADInaH kftaH, yadBAvi tadBa- <lb/>-vatu      ityuktvA sa parityaktaH.</s>   <b>-ment,</b>   <i>s.</i>   <lb/>   <s>tyAgaH, utsargaH;</s> ‘a. of worldly    con- <lb/>-nections’ <s>saMnyAsaH,      virakti</s>   <i>f.</i>  </body>  <tail>   <L>2</L>   <pc>001</pc>  </tail> </H1>
This structure was transformed into the following nested structure:
<entry ana="H1">  <form>   <orth ana="key1" xml:lang="en">abandon</orth>   <hyph ana="key2" xml:lang="en">Abandon,</hyph>  </form>  <sense>   <hi rendition="#i">v. t.</hi>   <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">tyaj</w> 1 P, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">hA</w> 3 P, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">vi-utsfj</w> 6 P, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">ujJ</w> 6 P, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">apAs</w> 4 P, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">Ri</w> 1 P, 10, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">muc</w> 6 P. </sense>  <sense>   <hi rendition="#b">2</hi>   <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">pApAtman, Brazwacarita;</w> ‘he    was a. to his fate’ <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">dEvADInaH      kftaH, yadBAvi tadBavatu ityuktvA sa parityaktaH.</w>  </sense>  <re>   <form norm="abandon-ed.">    <orth ana="key1" xml:lang="en">     <hi rendition="#b">-ed.</hi>    </orth>    <orth type="key1-combined">     <hi rendition="#b">abandon-ed.</hi>    </orth>   </form>   <sense>    <hi rendition="#i">a.</hi>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">tyakta, hIna, mukta</w>      &amp;c. </sense>   <sense>    <hi rendition="#b">2</hi>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">pApAtman, Brazwacarita;</w>      ‘he was a. to his fate’ <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">dEvADInaH kftaH, yadBAvi tadBavatu ityuktvA sa        parityaktaH.</w>   </sense>  </re>  <re>   <form norm="abandon-ment,">    <orth ana="key1" xml:lang="en">     <hi rendition="#b">-ment,</hi>    </orth>    <orth type="key1-combined">     <hi rendition="#b">abandon-ment,</hi>    </orth>   </form>   <sense>    <hi rendition="#i">s.</hi>    <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">tyAgaH, utsargaH;</w> ‘a. of      worldly connections’ <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">saMnyAsaH, virakti</w>    <hi rendition="#i">f.</hi>   </sense>  </re>  <note ana="tail">   <idno ana="L" xml:id="aptestud_2">2</idno>   <ref target="Fixme" type="facs">001</ref>  </note> </entry>

4. Grammatical information

The monier source file contained a lot of markup dealing with grammatical information spread through the whole entries.

4.1. Monier

4.1.1. Source file element lex

The element 'lex' in the Monier source file is used to mark grammatical information for substantives and indeclinables. For substantives this information is usually just the gender. Sometimes there is additional information.
<body>  <lex>n.</lex>  <c>act_of_dividing.</c> </body>
TEI version:
<sense>  <gramGrp>   <gram ana="lex">n.</gram>  </gramGrp> act of dividing. [...] </sense>

The element 'lex' can carry a @type attribute with various values. The attribut "type" in the source file was transformed to the TEI attribute value, please see list of possible values in element specification of <gram>.

4.1.2. Source file element vlex

The source element 'vlex' in the Monier source file marks inflectional information about verbs.
<vlex>cl.1 A1.</vlex>
TEI version:
<gramGrp>  <subc ana="vlex">cl.1    A1.</subc> </gramGrp>

The element 'vlex' can carry a @type attribute with various values. In the TEI file the attribute type was transformed to the TEI attribute value, please see list of valid values in element specification of <subc>.

4.1.3. Source file element 'root'

The source element 'root' in the Monier source file within 'key2' is used to specify the verbal root in prefixed verbs.
<key2>aMSI-<root>kf</root> </key2>
The TEI version makes use of the element <m>
<hyph ana="key2" xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aMSI-<m ana="root" type="preverb">kf</m> </hyph>
The empty element precedes the root in the source file:
<c>and_not_from_the_above</c>~<root/>~<s>aMS</s>~ <c>fictitiously_formed_to_serve_as_root</c>
The TEI version makes use of the element <milestone>
and not from the above <milestone unit="following_verb_root"/> <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aMS</w> fictitiously formed to serve as root)

4.2. PWG

Within the source file PWG grammatical information is marked by the element 'gram'.

No differentiation between gender like information and information concerning part-of-speech is made within the source file:
<body>  <gram n="m">m.</gram>  <wide>Vishn2u</wide> [...] </body>
The TEI version makes use of the element TEI-element <gram>
<sense>  <gramGrp>   <gram value="m">m.</gram>  </gramGrp>  <hi rendition="#wide"   xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">Vishn2u</hi> [...] > </sense>
<body>(3. <s>a + fRin) =    anfRin</s>  <gram n="adj">adj.</gram>  <i>frei von Schulden</i> [...]</body>
The TEI version makes use of the element TEI-element <gram>
<sense>(3. <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a + fRin) = anfRin</w>  <gramGrp>   <gram value="adj">adj.</gram>  </gramGrp>  <hi rendition="#i">frei von Schulden</hi> [...]</sense>

4.3. Apte

There is no markup within the aptestud source file dealing with grammatical information.

[Relevant TEI elements in use: <gram>, <gramGrp>, <subc>, <milestone>]

5. Transliteration systems and marking of languages

5.1. Keywords in Devanagari

Within the source files there was no explicit marking of the transliteration system used for the keywords in Devanagari.

Example from the Monier source file:
<h>  <hc3>110</hc3>  <key1>afRin</key1>  <hc1>1</hc1>  <key2>a-fRin</key2> </h>
The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang
<form>  <idno ana="hc3">110</idno>  <orth ana="key1"   xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a</orth>  <idno ana="hc1">1</idno>  <hyph ana="key2"   xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a</hyph>  <milestone n="6" unit="hom"/> </form>
Same for PWG, example from the PWG source file:
<h>  <key1>afRin</key1>  <key2>afRin</key2> </h>
TEI version:
<form>  <orth ana="key1"   xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">afRin</orth>  <hyph ana="key2"   xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">afRin</hyph> </form>

[Relevant TEI elements in use: <form>, <orth>, <hyph>]

5.2. Entries with words in Devanagari

Within entries the transliteration system used was marked by use of the elements "s"

Example from the Monier source file:
<cf/>~<s>a-kupya</s>~,~ <s>a-pUpa</s>
The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang
<w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a-kupya</w>, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">a-pUpa</w>
Example from the PWG source file:
<s>aMSu + mAlA</s>
The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang
<w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aMSu + mAlA</w>
Example from the Aptestud source file, witch is using Harvard Kyoto instead of SLP1:
<body>  <b>Abase,</b>  <i>v. t.</i>  <s>aBiBU</s> 1 P, <s>svasTAnAt nipat</s>  <lb/>[...] </body>
The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang
<sense>  <hi rendition="#i">v. t.</hi>  <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">aBiBU</w> 1 P, <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-HK">svasTAnAt nipat</w> [...] </sense>

5.2.1. Specific CDSL transliteration system

Another project specific transliteration system was used within the source files, especially in the context of abbreviations for literature (authors and works)

Example from the Monier source file:
<ls>Ta1n2d2yaBr.</ls>
The TEI version:
<cit type="literary_source">  <bibl xml:lang="san-Latn-x-CSDL">   <ref target="#auth-Ta1n2d2yaBr_">Ta1n2d2yaBr.</ref>  </bibl> </cit>
Example from the PWG source file:
<ls>AIT. BR. 2, 6.</ls>
The TEI version:
<cit type="literary_source">  <bibl xml:lang="san-Latn-x-CSDL">AIT. BR. 2, 6.</bibl> </cit>

[Relevant TEI elements in use: <w>]

5.3. Marking of languages

Example from the Monier source file:
<c>  <ab>cf.</ab>~<c1>   <ab>Goth.</ab>  </c1>~<etym>amsa</etym>~~;~~<c1>   <ab>Gk.</ab>_<gk>1</gk>_,_<gk>2</gk>_;_<ab>Lat.</ab>  </c1>~<etym>humerus</etym>~, </c>~ <etym>ansa</etym>
The TEI version replaces all the `gk` elements (+ numeric references) with <w ana="etym" xml:lang="el"> elements (+ Greek words). The `gk` elements were used to mark Greek words appearing in the dictionary. Instead of Greek words, the elements contain numeric references. The mechanism used to go from these numeric references to the corresponding Greek words is described in [the old place] . The TEI File uses the extra file `mwgreek.tei`, created by the conversion pipeline in `mwgreek`.
<abbr>  <ref target="#abbr-cf.">cf.</ref> </abbr> <abbr>  <ref target="#abbr-Goth.">Goth.</ref> </abbr> <w ana="etym" xml:lang="got">amsa</w> ; <abbr>  <ref target="#abbr-Gk.">Gk.</ref> </abbr> <w ana="etym" xml:lang="el">ὦμος</w>, <w ana="etym" xml:lang="el">ἄσιλλα</w> ; <abbr>  <ref target="#abbr-Lat.">Lat.</ref> </abbr> <w ana="etym" xml:lang="lat">humerus</w> , <w ana="etym" xml:lang="lat">ansa</w>.

All other languages were marked using the information that they are simply following the abbreviation for a languague (like '"Lat." enclosed in element "ab").

Example from the Monier source file:
<ab>Lat.</ab>[...]~<etym>humerus</etym>~,[...]~ <etym>ansa</etym>
TEI version:
<abbr>  <ref target="#abbr-Lat.">Lat.</ref> </abbr> <w ana="etym" xml:lang="lat">humerus</w> , <w ana="etym" xml:lang="lat">ansa</w>

[Relevant TEI elements in use: <w>]

6. Marking of special glyphs replacing single characters and abbreviation signs.

Within the Monier source file many elements can be found, serving as place holders for special characters or abbreviation signs etc.

For example 'srs within 'key2' stands for a hyphen
<key2>aMSA<srs/>MSa</key2>

To integrate this information into the TEI file and make it more explicit, we made use of <g>-elements pointing to <glyph> elements, stored in the <encodingDesc> of the <teiHeader.>.

Element <g> within the body of the Monier dictionary:
<hyph ana="key2" xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">aMSA<g ref="#glyph-key2_srs"/>MSa</hyph>
Pointing to the <teiHeader>
<encodingDesc>  <charDecl>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-sr">    <glyphName>sr</glyphName>    <mapping type="CSDL_nonTEI">°</mapping>    <mapping type="facsimile">°</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-sr1">    <glyphName>sr1</glyphName>    <mapping type="CSDL_nonTEI">°</mapping>    <mapping type="facsimile">°</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-fcom">    <glyphName>fcom</glyphName>    <mapping type="CDSL"/>    <mapping type="facsimile">̊</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-key2_srs">    <glyphName>key2_srs</glyphName>    <mapping type="CSDL_nonTEI">*</mapping>    <mapping type="facsimile">̂</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-srs">    <glyphName>srs</glyphName>    <mapping type="CSDL_nonTEI">*</mapping>    <mapping type="facsimile">̂</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-key2_srs1">    <glyphName>key2_srs1</glyphName>    <mapping type="CSDL_nonTEI">*</mapping>    <mapping type="facsimile">̂</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-srs1">    <glyphName>srs1</glyphName>    <mapping type="CSDL_nonTEI">*</mapping>    <mapping type="facsimile">̂</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-shortlong">    <glyphName>shortlong</glyphName>    <mapping type="CDSL"/>    <mapping type="facsimile">̄̆</mapping>   </glyph>   <glyph xml:id="glyph-shc">    <glyphName>shc</glyphName>    <mapping type="CSDL_nonTEI">-</mapping>    <mapping type="facsimile">̄̆</mapping>   </glyph>  </charDecl> </encodingDesc>

[Relevant TEI elements in use: <g>, <glyph>, <charDecl>]

7. Abbreviations in Monier

In monier three different kinds of abbreviations are used.

7.1. References to literature

The element "ls" was used to point to referenced works and authors listed in an external file.
<H4>  <h>   <hc3>102</hc3>   <key1>agnyADAnaSarkarA</key1>   <hc1>3</hc1>   <key2>agny-ADAna---Sarkar/A</key2>  </h>  <body>   <lex>f. <ab>pl.</ab>   </lex>   <p>figuratively</p>   <c>_bad_performance_of_the_<abE>A</abE>    <as0>Agnya1dheya</as0>    <as1>     <s>agnyADeya</s>    </as1>   </c>   <ls>S3Br.</ls>  </body>  <tail>   <pc>6,1</pc>   <L>1175.4</L>  </tail> </H4>
The TEI version uses the standard elements for bibliographic information
<cit type="literary_source">  <bibl xml:lang="san-Latn-x-CSDL">   <ref target="#auth-S3Br.">S3Br.</ref>  </bibl> </cit>
and links to the list of works and authors.

7.2. Simple abbreviations

Empty elements were used to point to a list of abbreviations stored in an external file.
<qv/>
The TEI version uses the standard element <abbr> and preserves the old element's name using type.
<abbr type="qv">  <ref target="#abbr-q.v.">q.v.</ref> </abbr>

7.3. Expansions added

The third one deals with abbreviated English and Anglicized Sanskrit in the text. The editors of the source file expanded the abbreviation right behind the closing element 'abE' or added the expansion using the elements 'as0' (singular) asp0 (plural) for "Sanskrit words which appear in the text in the 'indological' font" and the corresponding SLP encoding of the Sanskrit appears in a following "as1" :
form_or_shape_of_the_<abE>A</abE> <as0>Agnya1dheya</as0> <as1>  <s>agnyADeya</s> </as1>
form or shape of the <choice>  <abbr ana="abE">A</abbr>  <expan>   <choice>    <reg ana="as0"     xml:lang="san-Latn-x-CSDL">Agnya1dheya</reg>    <reg ana="as1">     <w xml:lang="san-Latn-x-SLP1">agnyADeya</w>    </reg>   </choice>  </expan> </choice>

The monier source file documentation adds: If the as1 element contains Sanskrit it includes an additional "s"-element. If it contains non-Sanskrit, the attribute type="ns" was added to the element as1.

[Relevant TEI elements in use: <abbr>, <expan>, <choice>, <reg>]

8. Editorial decisions

8.1. Existing information unused

The following elements are in the Monier source file, but were not preserved. In all cases the Monier source file pointed to this approach. Most of these elements are leftovers from past conversion processes.

The following comments are cited from the Monier source file documentation.

  • c | c1 | c2 | c3: These odd marking conventions were required to permit conversion back to the original form of `MONIER.ALL`. For a user of the XML version of the dictionary, they are probably best omitted (change `_` and `~` to a single space, delete `c`, etc.)
  • usage|idiom|sense|ellipsis|loan: The following are experimental markings; there is only one instance of each in the current markup of the dictionary.
  • ccom: Represents a character in MONIER.ALL used to represent certain complex records that needed further attention. Currently, there are only about 100 instances; these elements are probably now vestigial and should be removed.
  • TWOWORDS: An experimental coding for a headword composed of more than one word. Currently only appears once.
  • mscverb: Probably should be removed; originally inserted to identify records which were verbs with multiple parts separated by the 'msc' element.

Appendix A TEI-Specifications

This TEI Customization uses the modules core, tei, header, textstructure, dictionaries, transcr, analysis, tagdocs, linking, gaiji.

Appendix A.1 Elements

Appendix A.1.1 <TEI>

<TEI> (TEI document) contains a single TEI-conformant document, combining a single TEI header with one or more members of the model.resourceLike class. Multiple <TEI> elements may be combined to form a <teiCorpus> element. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Moduletextstructure
AttributesAttributes att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) (att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition)) (att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select)) (att.global.analytic (@ana)) (att.global.facs (@facs)) (att.global.change (@change)) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source)) att.typed (@type, @subtype)
versionspecifies the version number of the TEI Guidelines against which this document is valid.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.version
Note

Major editions of the Guidelines have long been informally referred to by a name made up of the letter P (for Proposal) followed by a digit. The current release is one of the many releases of the fifth major edition of the Guidelines, known as P5. This attribute may be used to associate a TEI document with a specific release of the P5 Guidelines, in the absence of a more precise association provided by the source attribute on the associated <schemaSpec>.

Contained by
—
May contain
header: teiHeader
textstructure: text
transcr: facsimile
Note

This element is required. It is customary to specify the TEI namespace http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0 on it, using the xmlns attribute.

Example
<TEI version="3.3.0" xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">  <teiHeader>   <fileDesc>    <titleStmt>     <title>The shortest TEI Document Imaginable</title>    </titleStmt>    <publicationStmt>     <p>First published as part of TEI P2, this is the P5          version using a name space.</p>    </publicationStmt>    <sourceDesc>     <p>No source: this is an original work.</p>    </sourceDesc>   </fileDesc>  </teiHeader>  <text>   <body>    <p>This is about the shortest TEI document imaginable.</p>   </body>  </text> </TEI>
Example
<TEI version="2.9.1" xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">  <teiHeader>   <fileDesc>    <titleStmt>     <title>A TEI Document containing four page images </title>    </titleStmt>    <publicationStmt>     <p>Unpublished demonstration file.</p>    </publicationStmt>    <sourceDesc>     <p>No source: this is an original work.</p>    </sourceDesc>   </fileDesc>  </teiHeader>  <facsimile>   <graphic url="page1.png"/>   <graphic url="page2.png"/>   <graphic url="page3.png"/>   <graphic url="page4.png"/>  </facsimile> </TEI>
Schematron
<s:ns prefix="tei"  uri="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"/> <s:ns prefix="xs"  uri="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"/>
Schematron
<s:ns prefix="rng"  uri="http://relaxng.org/ns/structure/1.0"/>
Content model
<content>
 <sequence>
  <elementRef key="teiHeader"/>
  <classRef key="model.resourceLike"
   maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
 </sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element TEI
{
   tei_att.global.attributes,
   tei_att.typed.attributes,
   attribute version { text }?,
   ( tei_teiHeader, tei_model.resourceLike+ )
}

Appendix A.1.2 <abbr>

<abbr> (abbreviation) contains an abbreviation of any sort. [3.5.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions]
Modulecore
AttributesAttributesatt.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition) att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select) att.global.facs (@facs) att.global.change (@change) att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source) att.typed (type, @subtype)
ana(analysis) Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.
Derived fromatt.global.analytic
StatusOptional
Datatype1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
abE
Monier source file documentation: This non-empty element represents the small superscript circle used with abbreviated English in the text. Typically, the letters of the abbreviation are the element contents, and the subsequent text is the un-abbreviated text. [the source file shows no small superscript circle]
etc
Monier source file documentation: Represent various kinds of '&c.' ; some alternate representation, more normally by an XML entity, is required for XML correctness.
etc1
Monier source file documentation: Represent various kinds of '&c.' ; some alternate representation, more normally by an XML entity, is required for XML correctness.
etcetc
Monier source file documentation: Represent various kinds of '&c.' ; some alternate representation, more normally by an XML entity, is required for XML correctness.
cf
Monier source file documentation: Confer. Sometimes refers to another word in dictionary; sometimes, to etymologies. Appears in text as 'c.f.' and is also coded as abbreviation c.f.
qf
Monier source file documentation: quod vide ('which see'). Usually refers to another word in dictionary. Appears in text as 'q.v.' or 'qq.vv.', and is also coded as abbreviation q.v.
typeallows the encoder to classify the abbreviation according to some convenient typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Sample values include:
suspension
the abbreviation provides the first letter(s) of the word or phrase, omitting the remainder.
contraction
the abbreviation omits some letter(s) in the middle.
brevigraph
the abbreviation comprises a special symbol or mark.
superscription
the abbreviation includes writing above the line.
acronym
the abbreviation comprises the initial letters of the words of a phrase.
title
the abbreviation is for a title of address (Dr, Ms, Mr, …)
organization
the abbreviation is for the name of an organization.
geographic
the abbreviation is for a geographic name.
Note

The type attribute is provided for the sake of those who wish to classify abbreviations at their point of occurrence; this may be useful in some circumstances, though usually the same abbreviation will have the same type in all occurrences. As the sample values make clear, abbreviations may be classified by the method used to construct them, the method of writing them, or the referent of the term abbreviated; the typology used is up to the encoder and should be carefully planned to meet the needs of the expected use. For a typology of Middle English abbreviations, see [[undefined PETTY]]

Member of
model.choicePart model.pPart.editorial
Contained by
analysis: pc span w
core: abbr add author bibl choice date desc editor expan head hi item label name note orig p pubPlace publisher quote ref reg resp rs sic term title unclear
dictionaries: dictScrap form gen gram gramGrp hyph orth re sense subc
header: authority change creation edition extent funder language licence principal rendition sponsor
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation orgName persName
tagdocs: eg valDesc
textstructure: docAuthor docDate titlePart
transcr: secl
May contain
analysis: c m pc span w
core: abbr add cb choice date expan graphic hi index lb milestone name note orig pb ptr ref reg rs sic term title unclear
gaiji: g
header: idno
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation orgName persName
tagdocs: att code gi ident specDesc specList tag val
transcr: secl
character data
Note

If abbreviations are expanded silently, this practice should be documented in the <editorialDecl>, either with a <normalization> element or a <p>.

Example
<choice>  <expan>North Atlantic Treaty Organization</expan>  <abbr cert="low">NorATO</abbr>  <abbr cert="high">NATO</abbr>  <abbr cert="high" xml:lang="fr">OTAN</abbr> </choice>
Example
<choice>  <abbr>SPQR</abbr>  <expan>senatus populusque romanorum</expan> </choice>
Content model
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element abbr
{
   tei_att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   tei_att.global.attribute.n,
   tei_att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   tei_att.global.attribute.xmlbase,
   tei_att.global.attribute.xmlspace,
   tei_att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   tei_att.global.rendition.attribute.style,
   tei_att.global.rendition.attribute.rendition,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.corresp,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.synch,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.sameAs,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.copyOf,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.next,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.prev,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.exclude,
   tei_att.global.linking.attribute.select,
   tei_att.global.facs.attribute.facs,
   tei_att.global.change.attribute.change,
   tei_att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   tei_att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   tei_att.global.source.attribute.source,
   tei_att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute ana
   {
      list { ( "abE" | "etc" | "etc1" | "etcetc" | "cf" | "qf" )+ }
   }?,
   attribute type { text }?,
   tei_macro.phraseSeq
}

Appendix A.1.3 <add>

<add> (addition) contains letters, words, or phrases inserted in the source text by an author, scribe, or a previous annotator or corrector. [3.4.3. Additions, Deletions, and Omissions]
Modulecore
AttributesAttributes att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) (att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition)) (att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select)) (att.global.analytic (@ana)) (att.global.facs (@facs)) (att.global.change (@change)) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source)) att.transcriptional (@status, @cause, @seq) (att.editLike (@evidence, @instant)) (att.written (@hand)) att.placement (@place) att.typed (@type, @subtype) att.dimensions (@unit, @quantity, @extent, @precision, @scope) (att.ranging (@atLeast, @atMost, @min, @max, @confidence))
Member of
model.pPart.transcriptional
Contained by
analysis: pc w
core: abbr add author bibl date editor expan head hi item label name note orig p pubPlace publisher quote ref reg rs sic term title unclear
dictionaries: dictScrap form gen gram gramGrp hyph orth re sense subc
header: change edition extent licence
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation orgName persName
tagdocs: eg
textstructure: docAuthor docDate titlePart
transcr: secl
May contain
analysis: c m pc span w
core: abbr add bibl biblStruct cb choice cit date desc expan graphic hi index label lb list listBibl milestone name note orig pb ptr quote ref reg rs sic term title unclear
gaiji: g
header: biblFull idno
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation orgName persName
tagdocs: att classSpec code constraintSpec dataSpec eg egXML elementSpec gi ident listRef macroSpec moduleSpec outputRendition specDesc specGrp specGrpRef specList tag val
transcr: secl
character data
Note

In a diplomatic edition attempting to represent an original source, the <add> element should not be used for additions to the current TEI electronic edition made by editors or encoders. In these cases, either the <corr> or <supplied> element are recommended.

In a TEI edition of a historical text with previous editorial emendations in which such additions or reconstructions are considered part of the source text, the use of <add> may be appropriate, dependent on the editorial philosophy of the project.

Example
The story I am going to relate is true as to its main facts, and as to the consequences <add place="above">of these facts</add> from which this tale takes its title.
Content model
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element add
{
   tei_att.global.attributes,
   tei_att.transcriptional.attributes,
   tei_att.placement.attributes,
   tei_att.typed.attributes,
   tei_att.dimensions.attributes,
   tei_macro.paraContent
}

Appendix A.1.4 <affiliation>

<affiliation> contains an informal description of a person's present or past affiliation with some organization, for example an employer or sponsor. [15.2.2. The Participant Description]
Modulenamesdates
AttributesAttributes att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) (att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition)) (att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select)) (att.global.analytic (@ana)) (att.global.facs (@facs)) (att.global.change (@change)) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source)) att.editLike (@evidence, @instant) att.datable (@calendar, @period) (att.datable.w3c (@when, @notBefore, @notAfter, @from, @to)) (att.datable.iso (@when-iso, @notBefore-iso, @notAfter-iso, @from-iso, @to-iso)) (att.datable.custom (@when-custom, @notBefore-custom, @notAfter-custom, @from-custom, @to-custom, @datingPoint, @datingMethod)) att.naming (@role, @nymRef) (att.canonical (@key, @ref)) att.typed (type, @subtype)
typecharacterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Sample values include:
sponsor
recommend
discredit
pledged
Member of
model.addressLike model.persStateLike
Contained by
analysis: span
core: abbr add author bibl date desc editor expan head hi item label name note orig p pubPlace publisher quote ref reg resp rs sic term title unclear
dictionaries: dictScrap form gen gram gramGrp hyph orth re sense subc
header: authority change correspAction creation edition extent funder language licence principal rendition sponsor
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation orgName persName persona
tagdocs: eg valDesc
textstructure: docAuthor docDate titlePart
transcr: secl
May contain
analysis: c m pc span w
core: abbr add cb choice date expan graphic hi index lb milestone name note orig pb ptr ref reg rs sic term title unclear
gaiji: g
header: idno
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation orgName persName
tagdocs: att code gi ident specDesc specList tag val
transcr: secl
character data
Note

If included, the name of an organization may be tagged using either the <name> element as above, or the more specific <orgName> element.

Example
<affiliation>Junior project officer for the US <name type="org">National Endowment for    the Humanities</name> </affiliation>
ExampleThis example indicates that the person was affiliated with the Australian Journalists Association at some point between the date ranges listed.
<affiliation notAfter="1960-01-01"  notBefore="1957-02-28">Paid up member of the <orgName>Australian Journalists Association</orgName> </affiliation>
ExampleThis example indicates that the person was affiliated with Mount Holyoke College throughout the entire span of the date ranges listed.
<affiliation from="1902-01-01"  to="1906-01-01">Was an assistant professor at Mount Holyoke College.</affiliation>
Content model
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>

   tei_att.naming.attributes,
   tei_att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute type { text }?,
   tei_macro.phraseSeq
}

Appendix A.1.5 <altIdent>

<altIdent> (alternate identifier) supplies the recommended XML name for an element, class, attribute, etc. in some language. [3.3.4. Terms, Glosses, Equivalents, and Descriptions 22.4.1. Description of Components]
Moduletagdocs
AttributesAttributes att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) (att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition)) (att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select)) (att.global.analytic (@ana)) (att.global.facs (@facs)) (att.global.change (@change)) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source)) att.typed (@type, @subtype)
Member of
model.glossLike
Contained by
tagdocs: attDef classSpec constraintSpec dataSpec elementSpec macroSpec model modelGrp modelSequence moduleSpec paramSpec schemaSpec valItem
May containCharacter data only
Note

All documentation elements in ODD have a canonical name, supplied as the value for their ident attribute. The <altIdent> element is used to supply an alternative name for the corresponding XML object, perhaps in a different language.

Example
<altIdent xml:lang="fr">balisageDoc</altIdent>
Content model
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element altIdent { tei_att.global.attributes, tei_att.typed.attributes, text }

Appendix A.1.6 <alternate>

<alternate> indicates that the constructs referenced by its children form an alternation [22.5.1. Defining Content Models]
Moduletagdocs
AttributesAttributes att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) (att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition)) (att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select)) (att.global.analytic (@ana)) (att.global.facs (@facs)) (att.global.change (@change)) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source)) att.repeatable (@minOccurs, @maxOccurs)
Member of
model.contentPart
Contained by
tagdocs: alternate content sequence
May contain
tagdocs: alternate anyElement classRef dataRef elementRef empty macroRef sequence textNode valList
Example
<content>  <alternate>   <elementRef key="name"/>   <elementRef key="persName"/>  </alternate> </content>
This example content model permits either a <name> or a <persName>.
Schematron
<sch:assert test="count(*)>1">The alternate element must have at least two child elements</sch:assert>
Content model
<content>
 <classRef key="model.contentPart"
  maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
</content>

{
   tei_att.global.attributes,
   tei_att.repeatable.attributes,

Appendix A.1.7 <anyElement>

<anyElement> indicates the presence of any elements in a content model [22. Documentation Elements]
Moduletagdocs
AttributesAttributes att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) (att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition)) (att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select)) (att.global.analytic (@ana)) (att.global.facs (@facs)) (att.global.change (@change)) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source)) att.repeatable (@minOccurs, @maxOccurs)
requiresupplies a list of namespaces to one of which the permitted elements must belong.
StatusOptional
Datatype1–∞ occurrences of teidata.namespace separated by whitespace
exceptsupplies a list of namespaces or prefixed element names which are not permitted.
StatusOptional
Datatype1–∞ occurrences of teidata.namespaceOrName separated by whitespace
Note

When RELAX NG DTD Compatibility Mode is turned on, validation requires that any elements which may take an xml:id be excluded from the content of anyName name classes. For normal TEI purposes, this includes anything in the TEI namespace and the <egXML> element. Default elements and namespaces to be excluded are set on the defaultExceptions attribute of the <schemaSpec>. except may be used when the exceptions need to be locally specified. Element prefixes must be declared using a namespace declaration on the parent or an ancestor element.

Member of
model.contentPart
Contained by
tagdocs: alternate content sequence
May containEmpty element
Example
<content>  <anyElement except="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"/> </content>
This <content> element permits one occurrence of any element which does not belong to the TEI namespace.
Example
<content>  <anyElement maxOccurs="unbounded"   minOccurs="1"   require="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML http://www.tei-c.org/ns/Examples/1.0"/> </content>
This <content> element permits one or more elements which belong either to the MathML namespace or to the TEI examples namespace.
Example
<content>  <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"   minOccurs="1">   <textNode/>   <anyElement require="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/Examples/1.0"/>  </alternate> </content>
This <content> element permits one or more children which are either text nodes or elements from the TEI examples namespace. It is the equivalent of the content model ANY in an XML DTD using the TEI All schema.
Content model
<content/>
Schema Declaration
element anyElement
{
   tei_att.global.attributes,
   tei_att.repeatable.attributes,
   attribute require { list { + } }?,
   attribute except { list { + } }?,
   empty
}

Appendix A.1.8 <appInfo>

<appInfo> (application information) records information about an application which has edited the TEI file. [2.3.10. The Application Information Element]
Moduleheader
AttributesAttributes att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang, @xml:base, @xml:space) (att.global.rendition (@rend, @style, @rendition)) (att.global.linking (@corresp, @synch, @sameAs, @copyOf, @next, @prev, @exclude, @select)) (att.global.analytic (@ana)) (att.global.facs (@facs)) (att.global.change (@change)) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source))

model.encodingDescPart
Contained by
header: encodingDesc
May contain
header: application
Example
<appInfo>  <application ident="Xaira" version="1.24">   <label>XAIRA Indexer</label>   <ptr target="#P1"/>  </application> </appInfo>
Content model

 <classRef key="model.applicationLike"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
